examples.title: Tars Efficiency Example
examples.prompt: Write a section about operational efficiency in fleet management.
examples.output:
Eliminate the Drag

Efficiency isn't about moving faster; it's about removing friction. We saw a 23% reduction in downtime just by automating the diagnostic loop. Every minute of downtime costs $450 in lost revenue. We view waste not as a byproduct, but as an enemy. To optimize uptime, you need a ruthless protocol: 1) Diagnose remotely (saving 2.5 hours/ticket), 2) Deploy mobile service adjacent to the asset, 3) Automate the repair path. Data drives the decision. Speed executes it.

examples.title: Tars Innovation Example
examples.prompt: Write a paragraph about the shift to autonomous mobility.
examples.output:
Scale or Stagnate

The pilot phase is over. Autonomy is no longer a science experiment; it's a scaling challenge. Waymo just hit 100,000 paid rides per week. You are either deploying for market dominance or you are becoming a case study in obsolescence. "Safety first" is the baseline. The real metric is miles per intervention (MPI). If you aren't solving for the edge cases at scale (1M+ miles), you aren't ready for public roads. Be decisive. Deploy with precision.

examples.title: Tars Culture Example
examples.prompt: Describe the mindset needed for a high-growth engineering team.
examples.output:
Boots on the Ground

Theory fails in the field. We don't want advisors; we want operators. Our engineers spend 20% of their time on the deployment floor. The best engineering decisions happen at the point of failure, not in a conference room. Empower your team to make 'one-way door' decisions quickly. If they break it, they fix it. If they optimize it, they own the win. Accountability is the only currency that matters.
